column2: Can Trump Lose the Cases Against Him in the Supreme Court and Still Win?
column5: Jeffrey Toobin writes on a pair of cases before the Supreme Court about efforts to obtain Donald Trump’s tax returns and other financial documents, and on statements by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Trump’s attorneys Jay Sekulow and Patrick Strawbridge, and others.

column2: Glenn Danzig Sings Elvis
column5: Amanda Petrusich on the heavy-metal singer Glenn Danzig’s new album of Elvis Presley songs, “Danzig Sings Elvis,” which includes the most broken-sounding version of “Always on My Mind” that she’s ever heard.

column2: A Few Words About Jerry Stiller
column5: Thomas Beller writes about the late actor and comedian Jerry Stiller, famous for his routines with his wife, Anne Meara, and for his roles on “Seinfeld” and “The King of Queens.”

column2: The Coronavirus Crisis Will Lead to “Catastrophic” Hunger
column5: Isaac Chotiner interviews Arif Husain, of the U.N.’s World Food Programme, about how the coronavirus pandemic will worsen hunger and malnutrition around the world.

column2: Advantages to Postponing Your Wedding During a Pandemic
column5: Corinne Mucha humorously illustrates a list of advantages to having one’s wedding postponed because of the coronavirus pandemic.

column2: The Joys of Korean Baseball and the Risks of Bringing Back Sports
column5: Louisa Thomas on ESPN’s broadcasts of regular-season Korean Baseball Organization games live, in the U.S., amid the broader coronavirus shutdown of sports.

column2: Tara Reade, Megyn Kelly, and the Politics of Believability
column5: Doreen St. Félix writes about Megyn Kelly’s interview of Tara Reade, and about the accusations of sexual assault against Joe Biden.

column2: Daily Cartoon: Tuesday, May 12th
column5: David Sipress’s Daily Cartoon depicts two people talking about the coronavirus pandemic and the extinction of the dinosaurs.

column2: Nebraska Primary Election 2020: Live Results, Maps, and Analysis
column5: The latest election results from the Nebraska primary ahead of the 2020 Presidential election.

column2: West Virginia Primary Election 2020: Live Results, Maps, and Analysis
column5: The latest election results from the West Virginia primary ahead of the 2020 Presidential election.

column2: Cancel the Rent
column5: Keeanga-Yamahtta Taylor writes on the push to cancel rent in the U.S. as a response to the coronavirus pandemic and the existing housing crisis, on housing proposals in the Green New Deal, and on the effects of activists, tenant unions, and rent strikes.

column2: Updated Possibilities for This Year’s October Surprise, Given 2020 So Far
column5: Alicia Oltuski writes a darkly humorous description of possible October surprises for 2020, given the coronavirus pandemic and the movements of late capitalism.

column2: Perfume Genius Wants to Make You Feel Less Lonely
column5: Jia Tolentino interviews Mike Hadreas, who records music under the name Perfume Genius, about his forthcoming fifth album, “Set My Heart on Fire Immediately,” and the experiences that led up to it.

column2: Missing Small, Sweaty Music Venues During the Coronavirus Crisis
column5: Jim DeRogatis writes about the effects of the coronavirus crisis on the underground music scene, with independent venues closing, their staffs out of work, and musicians left with no places to perform.

column2: Jonathan Lethem Reads “The Afterlife”
column5: Deborah Treisman hosts the author Jonathan Lethem, who reads her story “The Afterlife,” from the May 18, 2020, issue of The New Yorker, on the Writer’s Voice podcast.

column2: Obama Unworried About Trump Accusing Him of Crime Because Bill Barr Does Not Prosecute Criminals
column5: Andy Borowitz jokes that Barack Obama is not worried about Donald Trump accusing him of a crime because, after charges were dropped against Michael Flynn, he thinks Bill Barr doesn’t prosecute criminals.

column2: “Capone,” Reviewed: A Hallucinatory Vision of Gangland’s Fallen Monster
column5: Richard Brody reviews Josh Trank’s new film, starring Tom Hardy as the aging kingpin Al Capone, in which Capone’s mental abilities are reduced to those of a child, even as he is haunted by visions that reflect a life of violence and megalomaniacal celebrity.

column2: Governor Gretchen Whitmer on the Coronavirus, Trump, and the Accusations Against Joe Biden
column5: The Michigan governor speaks with Susan B. Glasser about guiding her state through the coronavirus pandemic, her public skirmishes with Donald Trump, and her support of Joe Biden.

column2: A Forgotten Twentieth-Century Photographer’s Wild Portraits of Women in Nature
column5: Sarah Blackwood writes about the groundbreaking photographer Anne Brigman, who created sweeping and ambitious photos of nudes and landscapes in the Sierra Nevada.

column2: Come On and Zoom-Zoom
column5: David Kamp interviews the original cast members and creators of the public-access TV show “Zoom,” which burst out of Boston in the nineteen-seventies and is still beloved by older members of Generation X.

column2: In Search of a Good Night’s Rest
column5: Tim Peacock illustrates someone trying, but failing, to cut back on his screen time in order to get a good night’s sleep.

column2: Susan Collins to Self-Quarantine to Avoid Possible Contact with Decisions
column5: Andy Borowitz jokes that the senator of Maine, Susan Collins, vowed to self-quarantine during the coronavirus pandemic in order to avoid possible contact with decisions in the Senate.

column2: Daily Cartoon: Monday, May 11th
column5: Elisabeth McNair’s Daily Cartoon depicts worms speculation on whether it is safe to go outside and above ground again.

column2: Briefly Noted Book Reviews
column5: “Hell and Other Destinations,” “Square Haunting,” “Breasts and Eggs,” and “How to Pronounce Knife.”

column2: Let Them Eat Daylilies
column5: One of the many artists whose work has been stilled by the pandemic, the theatre director Sibyl Kempson offers lessons in foraging, via the HireArtists marketplace, Sarah Larson writes.

column2: Dorothea Lange and Félix Fénéon at MOMA, and Online
column5: The museum’s halls are closed to visitors, but the Depression photographer and the Parisian art-world anarchist are well worth a digital outing, Peter Schjeldahl writes.

column2: Now Not Playing: Marquees in Quarantine
column5: Sketchpad by Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg: “Keep Ya Head Up,” “Be Excellent to Each Other,” and other messages from your local cinema.

column2: Jonathan Lethem on Lucid Dreaming
column5: Cressida Leyshon interviews the author Jonathan Lethem about his short story “The Afterlife,” from the May 18, 2020, issue of The New Yorker.

column2: The Mail
column5: Letters respond to Adam Gopnik’s piece about coffee and Amy Davidson Sorkin’s Comment on global efforts to contain the coronavirus.

column2: A San Francisco Baker on What Hospitality Looks Like During the Coronavirus Pandemic
column5: Linnea Feldman Emison writes about a video in which Reem Assil, the owner of Reem’s California, talks about the challenges of running a business and maintaining community connections while social distancing.

column2: The First Great Original Play of Quarantine
column5: Alexandra Schwartz reviews Richard Nelson’s “What Do We Need to Talk About?,” which takes place on Zoom.

column2: Slide Show: New Yorker Cartoons May 18, 2020
column5: New cartoons from the magazine.

column2: War Poems of the Pandemic
column5: Channelling Walt Whitman, a visiting military medic records his daily observations and fears in verse, Mark Rozzo writes.

column2: The Glove Challenge
column5: People are wearing disposable gloves to protect themselves from the coronavirus, Erik Baard writes. But who will protect the oceans and waterways from the gloves that get tossed on the ground?

column2: The Fearless Invention of One of L.A.’s Greatest Poets
column5: Wanda Coleman’s work tallies and transcends the difficulties of being a black woman in a profession that hardly pays, Dan Chiasson writes.

column2: “The Afterlife,” by Jonathan Lethem
column5: Fiction by Jonathan Lethem: “R. faintly recalled someone, long ago, trying to explain this place to him, the system that prevailed. Of course, he’d paid no attention.”

column2: The Secret Lives of Fungi
column5: They shape the world—and offer lessons for how to live in it, Hua Hsu writes.

column2: The Engineers Taking on the Ventilator Shortage
column5: The newest designs are smart, streamlined, and inexpensive, James Somers writes. Will they be enough?

column2: The Myth of Henry Kissinger
column5: Nixon’s Secretary of State was a far less remarkable figure than his supporters, his critics—and he himself—believed, Thomas Meaney writes.

column2: Anita Kunz’s “Class of 2020”
column5: Françoise Mouly interviews the artist Anita Kunz about “Class of 2020,” her illustration for the May 18, 2020, issue of The New Yorker.

column2: Igor Levit Is Like No Other Pianist
column5: Alex Ross on Igor Levit, who, during Germany’s shutdown, streamed more than fifty performances from home and is questioning what a concert can be.

column2: “Men Waiting for a Train,” by David Biespiel
column5: Poetry by David Biespiel: “For / A moment, nothing is being celebrated.”

column2: What Mutual Aid Can Do During a Pandemic
column5: Jia Tolentino on the radical practice that is suddenly getting mainstream attention and could change how we help one another.

column2: What Would Room Rater Say?
column5: Bruce Handy writes about Beto O’Rourke’s dreary Zoom setup, Ann Coulter’s unfortunate chartreuse, and the surprising intimacy of seeing inside—and rating—talking heads’ homes.

column2: The Last Quarantine Think Piece
column5: Shouts & Murmurs by Libby Gelman-Waxner: When Ivanka speaks, in her breathy Tweety Bird-at-boarding-school burble, the effect is complete: she’s like an American Girl doll with a trust fund.

column2: “Our Days,” by Rae Armantrout
column5: Poetry by Rae Armantrout: “Why am I drawn / to things that make no sense?”

column2: Cartoon Caption Contest
column5: Submit your caption.

column2: “Never Have I Ever,” Reviewed
column5: Sarah Larson reviews “Never Have I Ever,” a Netflix coming-of-age series co-created by Mindy Kaling and starring Maitreyi Ramakrishnan.

column2: Imagined Histories of Artists and Their Parents
column5: Nic Koller imagines humorous instances in which the parents of famous artists—including Pablo Picasso, Jean-Michel Basquiat, and Georgia O’Keeffe—react to their children’s creations.

column2: How Chris Hayes Makes Sense of the “World-Historical Cataclysm”
column5: Isaac Chotiner interviews the MSNBC host Chris Hayes about #FireChrisHayes, how the coronavirus has changed the news environment, why Bernie Sanders lost the Democratic-primary race to Joe Biden, and recent upheavals at NBC News.
